newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil hopes to raise $24 bln in property sales.
newsitem.headline: Brazil hopes to raise $24 bln in property sales.

text.p: The cash-strapped Brazilian government hopes to raise up to $24.5 billion by selling off property it does not use and in some cases does not even know it owns, an official said on Monday.

Helio Carlos Gehrke, the Finance Ministry official charged with looking after the government's diverse apartments, buildings, beaches and islands, told reporters he hoped to identify as federally-owned three million properties by the year 2001.
"So far, we have registered 500,000," he said.
Brazil has faced an uphill battle to rein in its spending and balance its books. It has introduced voluntary lay offs for federal employees and is privatizing state-owned companies.
Last year, officials revealed they had no idea how many buildings were federally owned and that the $280 million earned a year in rent by the government should probably be more like $2.0 billion.

Gehrke said occupants of property found to belong to the government would be allowed to buy it. They would pay land rent of 0.6 percent a year over the value of the property, raising some $1.45 billion a year for the government.
Gehrke said that by the year 2010, Brasilia expected to have made up to $24.5 billion selling 210,000 properties a year.
